description: From French interner, from interne (“inner, internal”), from Latin internus (“within, internal”), compare Etymology 2.

adjectives.description: intern (comparative more intern, superlative most intern)

entries.meaning: A person who is interned, forcibly or voluntarily.

verbs.description: intern (third-person singular simple present interns, present participle interning, simple past and past participle interned)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To imprison somebody, usually without trial.

entries.meaning: (of a state, especially a neutral state) To confine or hold (foreign military personnel who stray into the state's territory) within prescribed limits during wartime.
examples: The Swiss government interned the Italian soldiers who had strayed onto Swiss territory.
Strings are automatically interned if they are assigned to a literal string within code.

description: From French interne (“inner, internal”), from Latin internus (“within, internal”), from inter (“between”); compare etymology 1.

entries.meaning: A student or recent graduate who works in order to gain experience in their chosen field.
A medical student or recent graduate working in a hospital as a final part of medical training.

verbs.description: intern (third-person singular simple present interns, present participle interning, simple past and past participle interned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To work as an intern. Usually with little or no pay or other legal prerogatives of employment, for the purpose of furthering a program of education.
examples: I'll be interning at Universal Studios this summer.
